title: Window Opener Property Bug

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
The bug mentioned in #23386 is not yet correctly patched I believe.

See, if a user sets his/her profile's website link to a similar page as mentioned in #23386. I mean a page that can manipulate the window.opener property would be able to accomplish similar results as in #23386

**Proof-of-Concept**:

1. Login to HackerOne
2. Navigate to https://hackerone.com/settings/profile/edit
3. Set *Website* to https://demo.prakharprasad.com/ga.html
4. Once someone visits this link from a profile page  (eg. https://hackerone.com/<username->), his opener HackerOne window will be hijacked.

Let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks,
Prakhar Prasad
vulnerability_information_html:
The bug mentioned in #23386 is not yet correctly patched I believe.

See, if a user sets his/her profile's website link to a similar page as mentioned in #23386. I mean a page that can manipulate the window.opener property would be able to accomplish similar results as in #23386

Proof-of-Concept:

  1. Login to HackerOne
  2. Navigate to https://hackerone.com/settings/profile/edit
  3. Set Website to https://demo.prakharprasad.com/ga.html
  4. Once someone visits this link from a profile page (eg. https://hackerone.com/<username->), his opener HackerOne window will be hijacked.

Let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks,
Prakhar Prasad

activities.message: Thank you for sending this in! This one seems trickier to fix, since we are not using the redirect interstitial here, which means that `window.opener = null;` won't suffice here. While we investigate other options, any ideas from your side are welcome as well!
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for sending this in! This one seems trickier to fix, since we are not using the redirect interstitial here, which means that window.opener = null; won't suffice here. While we investigate other options, any ideas from your side are welcome as well!

activities.message:
I believe it will be more neat if you can implement the redirect interstitial here. I strongly *think* that all external links originating from HackerOne, regardless of their origin (profile, bug report etc.) should go through a redirect interstitial. 

What's your take on this ?
activities.markdown_message:
I believe it will be more neat if you can implement the redirect interstitial here. I strongly think that all external links originating from HackerOne, regardless of their origin (profile, bug report etc.) should go through a redirect interstitial.

What's your take on this ?

activities.message: Yep, that is probably the most straightforward way to fix this. Another solution would be to remove the `target="_blank"` in those links, so there is no `window.opener` to hijack. We'll discuss internally and will follow up shortly.
activities.markdown_message: Yep, that is probably the most straightforward way to fix this. Another solution would be to remove the target="_blank" in those links, so there is no window.opener to hijack. We'll discuss internally and will follow up shortly.

activities.message: BTW  I'm just curious to know, why there wasn't a redirect interstitial in the profile page ?
activities.markdown_message: BTW I'm just curious to know, why there wasn't a redirect interstitial in the profile page ?

activities.message: The redirect interstitial is intentionally only used in the report interface to protect against accidental clicks on POCs.
activities.markdown_message: The redirect interstitial is intentionally only used in the report interface to protect against accidental clicks on POCs.

activities.message: Ah, I see. I hope you guys will add it to *all external links*
activities.markdown_message: Ah, I see. I hope you guys will add it to all external links

activities.message: We're experimenting with a few solutions, short term fix could be removing `target="_blank"` and long term fix could be a redirect page for all external links with potentially a few whitelisted URLs.
activities.markdown_message: We're experimenting with a few solutions, short term fix could be removing target="_blank" and long term fix could be a redirect page for all external links with potentially a few whitelisted URLs.

activities.message:
I found a way for Chrome browser, if you set `rel=noreferrer` in the anchor then `window.opener` will be automatically set to `null`

But this doesn't work for others I guess (confirmed not working in Firefox/Safari)
activities.markdown_message:
I found a way for Chrome browser, if you set rel=noreferrer in the anchor then window.opener will be automatically set to null

But this doesn't work for others I guess (confirmed not working in Firefox/Safari)

activities.message: Quick update: we're currently testing a fix in production. Can you see if this fixes the vulnerability? It'll likely take one more iteration of finetuning.
activities.markdown_message: Quick update: we're currently testing a fix in production. Can you see if this fixes the vulnerability? It'll likely take one more iteration of finetuning.

activities.message:
Thanks for the bounty, though credit still goes to @thetime. I believe there should be some finetuning of the redirection process, as the redirection happens in a split second without user being able to read the message itself.

And please - **I don't want to make this report public at the moment, may be in future, so kindly don't ask for disclosure for this bug**
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the bounty, though credit still goes to @thetime. I believe there should be some finetuning of the redirection process, as the redirection happens in a split second without user being able to read the message itself.

And please - I don't want to make this report public at the moment, may be in future, so kindly don't ask for disclosure for this bug

activities.message:
Yes, we're still working on some finetuning there. At least the most important part, the tab hijacking part, is fixed now.

Can I ask why you don't want to make this public? We prefer to have all bugs that we paid for and fixed to be public.

activities.message: Ah I see, let me know if I can contribute in that finetuning process or anything else.
activities.markdown_message: Ah I see, let me know if I can contribute in that finetuning process or anything else.

activities.message:
I know you guys prefer to make all bugs public, *I'm keeping it private atm as I don't have any specific intentions/reasons to make this bug public*. I know many people learn from existing reports but this bug/technique is already made public by @thetime, so doesn't make much difference, in this philosophy either. 

So just some privacy atm, nothing else.

activities.message:
@michiel: Don't you think, the redirection process your team has implemented can be *still* abused as open redirect, because: 

- Whole process completes quickly (less than a second or so, but you said it will be finetuned later)
- Your redirection has a *signature* parameter associated with it, eg:

hackerone.com/redirect/secure?signature= **6729d64046a8977dc43653c1caa2305de4296879** &url=https%3A%2F%2Fprakharprasad.com%2F

But I believe the **signature** parameter can be derived for a malicious link by simply setting your own profile's URL to a malicious one and then copying it from the profile page (it will contain the signature as well with it) and sending it to someone, hence sort of open redirect.


Let me know if my observations are correct or I missed something here.
activities.markdown_message:
@michiel: Don't you think, the redirection process your team has implemented can be still abused as open redirect, because:

  • Whole process completes quickly (less than a second or so, but you said it will be finetuned later)
  • Your redirection has a signature parameter associated with it, eg:

hackerone.com/redirect/secure?signature= 6729d64046a8977dc43653c1caa2305de4296879 &url=https%3A%2F%2Fprakharprasad.com%2F

But I believe the signature parameter can be derived for a malicious link by simply setting your own profile's URL to a malicious one and then copying it from the profile page (it will contain the signature as well with it) and sending it to someone, hence sort of open redirect.

Let me know if my observations are correct or I missed something here.

activities.message: Instead of increasing the wait time on the passthrough page (this was the finetuning I was talking about in my previous comment), we decided to remove the entire passthrough redirect functionality. This scenario should no longer be possible.
activities.markdown_message: Instead of increasing the wait time on the passthrough page (this was the finetuning I was talking about in my previous comment), we decided to remove the entire passthrough redirect functionality. This scenario should no longer be possible.

activities.message: I believe it is the right time to disclose ;)
